Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story:
I was just settling into my shift as a telemarketer, headset snug and script ready, when my phone buzzed with a message from Mark, an old acquaintance. “Hey, could you help me move some boxes this afternoon? I’m moving apartments and could really use an extra hand.” I stared at the message, feeling a familiar tug. Mark and I weren’t close, but we’d always been friendly, and I knew he didn’t have many people to ask. I wanted to help—wasn’t that what friends, even distant ones, were supposed to do?

But my supervisor had just reminded us that we needed to be available for every call, especially since our campaign was going so well. Most callers were easy, just a few questions here and there, all covered by the script. Still, I was expected to be present, to handle every objection smoothly, to keep the numbers up. If I left early or got distracted, I’d be letting my team down. My phone buzzed again—Mark, asking if I’d seen his message. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between being the helpful acquaintance and the reliable telemarketer, unsure which expectation I could afford to disappoint.
